author: tersec
content:
Nimbus can't really do this yet without ugly hacks without one of:
- adding a new wrapper around `recover_cells_and_kzg_proofs` either in the main `nimbus-eth2` repository or in the `nim-kzg4844` wrapper; or

- Nimbus points `nim-kzg4844` (which we use to access `c-kzg-4844` to a random branch (https://github.com/ethereum/c-kzg-4844/pull/594) which will disappear at some point and also mean that when people try to `git checkout` older commits of Nimbus, they'll fail because, oops, a dependent vendored branch disappeared because it was not the main development branch.

It would have been better to merge https://github.com/ethereum/c-kzg-4844/pull/594 before releasing alpha.6 specs and unless you say it's an emergency which must be done ASAP, I'm going to hold off until it is merged and I can just bump `c-kzg-4844` to a `main` branch commit to fix it.

Of course, I can just add a workaround to the tests, and I did to test that it worked, but that doesn't scale and just makes the tests run different code than the rest of Nimbus.

author: garyrong
content:
Hi everyone, I have a question regarding `engine_getBlobsV1`.

In Geth v1.16.3, we introduced a behavioral change:
- Previously: if a requested blob was not found locally, we would silently ignore it and return the rest. The missing blob would be returned as nil.
- Now: if any requested blob is missing, the entire request is treated as invalid and an error is returned instead.

Do you guys know which one is the expected behavior?

author: pawandhananjay
content:
Sorry just saw this, 
For lighthouse, 
scenario 1: we return an empty response
scenario 2: we return empty responses for the zero blob columns
scenario 3: we actively try to avoid this scenario. If a lighthouse peer advertises something and doesn't send a response for it, its a bug that we need to fix. i'm seeing quite a few lodestar peers doing this on devnet 3 btw

author: greystroke
content:
Looking at the validator queues and the consistent increase in 0x02 validators, i think the majority of the exit queue is a combination of large stakers consolidating (since batch consolidations essentially broken) and arbitage of the stETH/ETH depeg.  I think only a minority of it is for liquidity reasons. 
The entrance queue is the other half of these actions plus DATs staking their ETH mostly.
I think the difficulty in consolidating many validators in a single batch tx a real issue here.  It should be possible to consolidate 64 0x01 32ETH validators into a one 2048 ETH 0x02 validator in a single tx on an accelerated pathway.  This should be a priority for network health & functionality.  Afterall,  validator consolidation for larger node operators is important for network scalability and more efficient p2p gossiping.
